By Kiyoshi Takenaka
| TOKYO
TOKYO Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to underscore the importance of the Japan-U.S. alliance when he meets President-elect Donald Trump on Thursday
column2: Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida said on Sunday.""This is going to be an important meeting to build trust
column3: Kishida told public broadcaster NHK. ""We also would like to use this opportunity to input the importance of the Japan-U.S. alliance
column4: as well.""With Abe set to meet Trump in New York on his way to an Asia-Pacific summit in Peru
column5: Tokyo has been seeking clarity on what direction the Republican political novice wants for bilateral relations after he made comments on the campaign trail that were at odds with longstanding policies.

column1: Kishida reiterated Japan's long-standing position that it has no plans to possess nuclear weapons. During his campaign
column2: Trump left open the possibility that Japan - the only country to have suffered a nuclear bombing - might adopt nuclear weapons.""I don't believe Japan will possess nuclear arms. This principle won't change
column3: Kishida said.

column1: Trump's campaign comments on Japan's nuclear armament and his demand that Japan pay more for the upkeep of U.S. forces on its soil have worried Tokyo about a possible rift in a security alliance with Washington that has been the bedrock of its defense since World War Two.Defence Minister Tomomi Inada told the same NHK program that Japan is already shouldering enough financial burden to support U.S. troops deployed in Japan.
Japan is making sufficient contribution
column2: she said. ""I would like to continue underscoring that Japan is going to strengthen its own defense posture both in quality and quantity
column3: strengthen the Japan-U.S. alliance and strengthen ties with other relevant countries."" (Reporting by Kiyoshi Takenaka; Editing by William Mallard and Michael Perry)"	['Trump']	[]

2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-obamacare-idUSKBN1370AV	Some Republicans see attacking Obamacare through regulation	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Congressional Republicans are looking for the quickest ways to tear down Obamacare following Donald Trump's election as U.S. president
column2: including rapidly confirming a new health secretary who could recast regulations while waiting for lawmakers to pass sweeping repeal legislation.Trump's victory on Tuesday means Republicans will control the White House
column3: Senate and House of Representatives. But congressional Democrats are expected to put up a huge fight against Republican efforts to repeal the 2010 law considered President Barack Obama's signature domestic policy achievement.The Affordable Care Act
column4: dubbed Obamacare
column5: has provided 25 million previously uninsured Americans with health coverage. Republicans have launched repeated legal and legislative efforts to dismantle the law
column6: which they call a government overreach.Wyoming Senator John Barrasso
column7: a member of Senate Republican leadership
column8: said one way for the incoming president and Congress to attack Obamacare immediately after Trump takes office on Jan. 20 would be to quickly confirm a new secretary of Health and Human Services
column9: the official who writes the rules and regulations that enforce the law.""We could confirm someone on Jan. 20 who could come in immediately and could be working right now on rewriting rules and regulations to give more freedom and choice to the states
column10: to insurance companies and to businesses that are trying to provide affordable care to their workers
column11: Barrasso said in a telephone interview.Barrasso noted that the Senate needs only a simple majority vote in the 100-seat chamber to confirm Cabinet members
column12: as opposed to 60 votes to overcome procedural hurdles the Democrats could present to repeal legislation.Passing repeal legislation ""is not a 'Day One' activity. But a new secretary of HHS going after the regulations can be a 'Day One' activity
column13: Barrasso added.Trump during the campaign called Obamacare ""a disaster"" and joined fellow Republicans in vowing to repeal and replace it with proposals like tax-free health savings accounts. His transition website says Trump wants a solution that ""returns the historic role in regulating health insurance to the states.""

column1: In repealing Obamacare
column2: congressional Republican may have to resort to a special procedure known as reconciliation to get around Democrats in the Senate
column3: where rules protect the rights of the minority party.Republicans in Congress used reconciliation to try to undo large chunks of Obamacare in January
column4: but Obama vetoed the legislation. The bill would have wiped out tax subsidies provided to help people afford insurance coverage
column5: as well as tax penalties on people who do not obtain insurance as required by the law
column6: and would have eliminated expansion of the Medicaid insurance health insurance program. Republican Representative Chris Collins of New York
column7: one of Trump's earliest supporters on Capitol Hill
column8: said he hopes Congress can pass a similar bill gutting Obamacare within Trump's first 100 days in office
column9: a promise Trump made during the presidential campaign. But some changes will doubtless be phased in over time
column10: Collins said.""There's nothing that we will be able to do or would want to do that would impact anyone's health insurance plan for 2017

column1: From a replacement standpoint
column2: our position has always been as Republicans to move forward in a step-by-step fashion
column3: Barrasso said.In an interview with the Wall Street Journal published on Friday
column4: Trump said he was considering retaining parts of Obamacare including provisions letting parents keep adult children up to age 26 on their insurance policies and barring insurers from denying coverage to people with pre-existing medical conditions.MORE FLEXIBILITY

column1: While waiting for Congress to act on legislation
column2: the new HHS secretary could be reworking Obamacare regulations
column3: Barrasso said. For example
column4: regulations could give U.S. states more flexibility under a provision that lets states seek waivers from key provisions of the law
column5: such as exemptions from the so-called individual mandate requiring Americans to obtain insurance and the employer mandate to provide it.Kim Monk
column6: an analyst at Capital Alpha Partners
column7: which provides policy research to financial institutions
column8: said Trump's HHS might be able to tighten up the rules governing special enrollment periods for Obamacare. Insurers complain that these periods have allowed some people who initially skipped buying insurance to sign up after becoming ill.HHS might also be able to alter the language on ""essential benefits"" that the law requires insurance plans to cover
column9: which include trips to the emergency room
column12: Monk said.""The law requires they have to cover 10 essential health benefit categories
column14: a lot of that is interpretative
column16: everything the Obama administration interpreted was more
column20: and all these things lead to premium increases.""Collins
column21: a member of the Trump transition team's executive committee
column22: said the job of HHS secretary or surgeon general ""would be great for Ben Carson
column23: referring to the neurosurgeon who ran unsuccessfully for the Republican presidential nomination and later endorsed Trump. (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; Editing by Will Dunham)"	['Obama'

By Steve Holland and Luciana Lopez
| WASHINGTON/NEW YORK
WASHINGTON/NEW YORK President-elect Donald Trump began laying the groundwork on Friday to take office on Jan. 20
column3: gathering the most loyal advisers from his insurgent campaign and three of his children to plot his transition strategy.Trump put Vice President-elect Mike Pence in charge of his White House transition team
column4: while demoting his former transition chief
column5: tarnished New Jersey Governor Chris Christie
column6: to one of the six vice-chair posts. Daughter Ivanka and sons Eric and Donald Jr. and son-in-law Jared Kushner accounted for a fourth of the 16-member executive committee
column7: which was filled with politicians and advisers who stuck with Trump during his rollercoaster first run for public office. Aides huddled in the real-estate mogul's Trump Tower in New York City to begin prioritizing policy changes and considering Cabinet picks and other candidates for the 4
column8: 000 positions he will need to fill shortly after he takes the reins of the White House.A member of the Trump transition team told Reuters there were more than 100 people now involved in developing ""white papers"" on what regulations to roll back after Jan. 20. Some environmental measures and a rule requiring retirement advisers to act in their clients' interests could be among the first on the chopping block
column9: an industry lobbying source said.Trump promised during his campaign to cut taxes
column10: clamp down on immigration and repeal President Barack Obama's signature Affordable Care Act
column11: popularly known as Obamacare. But in interviews with the Wall Street Journal and CBS ""60 Minutes"" on Friday
column12: he said he was open to keeping some provisions of Obamacare.James Woolsey
column13: a former CIA director who has advised Trump on foreign policy
column14: said several of Trump's campaign promises were ""advocacy of a general direction"" that may require compromise - including his signature pledge to build a wall on the border with Mexico.Woolsey told CNN that border security could be achieved with a combination of fence and wall. ""I don't think we ought to fall on our sword about the difference between a wall and fence. Maybe this will be cheaper because it's mainly fence
column15: but it's a good fence. I wouldn't have any problem with that myself
column18: also moved on Friday to extricate himself from his sprawling business empire
column19: which will be overseen by his three grown children on the transition team. His company said it was vetting new business structures for the transfer of control to the three and the arrangement would not violate conflict-of-interest laws. But government ethics experts said the move would fall short of blind trust standards and was unlikely to prevent potential conflicts of interest.

column1: Trump said that Pence - who has strong ties to Republican leaders in Congress - will build on work done by Christie and has the mission of assembling ""the most highly qualified group of successful leaders who will be able to implement our change agenda in Washington."" Christie

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-trade-tpp-idUSKBN13629G	Obama administration suspends Pacific trade deal vote effort	"
By David Lawder
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama's administration has suspended its  efforts to win congressional approval for his Asian free-trade deal before President-elect Donald Trump takes office
column2: saying on Friday that TPP's fate was up to Trump and Republican lawmakers.Administration officials also said Obama would try to explain the situation to leaders of the 11 other countries in the Trans-Pacific Partnership pact next week when he attends a regional summit in Peru.  Obama's cabinet secretaries and the U.S. Trade Representative's office had been lobbying lawmakers for months to pass the 12-country Trans-Pacific Partnership deal in the post-election
column3: lame-duck session of Congress. However
column4: Trump's stunning election victory that sends him to the White House in January and retains Republican majorities in Congress has stymied those plans.""We have worked closely with Congress to resolve outstanding issues and are ready to move forward
column5: but this is a legislative process and it's up to congressional leaders as to whether and when this moves forward
column6: USTR spokesman Matt McAlvanah said in a statement.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said he would not take up TPP in the weeks before Trump's inauguration and said its fate was now up to Trump. House Speaker Paul Ryan had earlier said he would not proceed with a lame-duck vote. Trump made his opposition to the TPP a centerpiece of his campaign
column3: calling it a ""disaster"" and ""a rape of our country"" that would send more jobs overseas. His anti-free-trade message and pledges to stem the tide of imported goods from China and Mexico won him massive support among blue-collar workers in the industrial heartland states of Ohio
column4: Michigan
column5: Wisconsin and Pennsylvania
column6: helping to swing the election his way.

column1: Trump has said he will scrap TPP
column2: renegotiate the 22-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement and adopt a much tougher trade stance with China.The TPP agreement
column3: negotiated for more than five years and signed in October 2015
column4: was aimed at reducing trade barriers erected by some of the fastest growing economies in Asia and boosting ties with U.S. allies in the region in the face of China's rising influence.
